Hashes serve a variety of functions in computers, but in networking, they are mostly employed for authentication and data integrity. Hash function: A mathematical procedure that turns any length sequence of binary digits into a fixed-length number. Any given input always yields the same result. Header: The first component of a frame, packet, segment, or datagram comprises important data transmission information such as destination and source addresses. Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC): The equipment used to heat and cool the environs within a facility. Boilers, furnaces, air conditioners, ducts, plenums, and air tunnels are examples of these things. Hex (hexadecimal): A numbering scheme based on the number 16 (i.e., one with 16 symbols). It represents binary numbers in a more human-friendly format by using 10 digits (0 through 9) and 6 letters (A through F). Hexadecimal 9 corresponds to decimal 9, whereas hexadecimal A corresponds to decimal 10. High availability (HA): A set of technologies and practices that work together to ensure that an application is always available. History logs: Logs that record how a user or users access network resources, or how network resources are accessible across the network. Home automation: Remote control of household gadgets such as lights, thermostats, cameras, and washing machines and dryers. honeynet: A network that contains one or more honeypots designed to attract hackers. Honeypot: A resource placed up by an administrator with the explicit purpose of enticing a computer hacker, frequently utilizing fictitious data and intentional weaknesses as bait. If a hacker falls for the bait, the network's critical resources will be untouched, and network personnel will be able to evaluate the attack to forecast and protect against future assaults, making the network more secure. Hop count: An ancient measure that is still used by RIP routers. The number of routers that a packet must pass through to get from one router to another on a given network. Hop counts were recorded and placed into a router's routing table so that the router could determine which interface was the best for forwarding a packet. Horizontal cabling: Cabling running from the equipment room to the work areas. Host: A single device (typically a computer) with an IP address on a TCP/IP network; any device that can be the source or destination of a data packet. A machine that runs numerous virtualized operating systems. Host-based anti-malware: Anti-malware software that is installed on individual systems rather than the entire network. Host-based firewall: A software firewall installed on a "host" that only serves as a firewall for that system, such as Windows Firewall. Hosts file: A static text file that is stored on a computer and is used to resolve DNS hostnames to IP addresses. In current systems, DNS resolver caches are automatically mapped to hosts. The hosts file does not have an extension. Host-to-host: A VPN connection in which a single host connects to a remote, single host. Host-to-site: A VPN connection in which a host logs into a faraway network as if it were any other local network resource. Hot site: A complete backup facility to keep business activities running. It is deemed "hot" because all resources, including computers, network infrastructure, and current backups, are in place and operations can begin within hours of occupation. Hotspot: A wireless access point linked to a cellular data network, usually 4G. Wi-Fi can be routed to and from the device. Hotspots can be either permanent or portable. Many cellular phones have the capacity to function as a hotspot. Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP): A Cisco-exclusive FHRP that provides greater data availability through redundancy. Hub: A central electronic device in a star topology network that serves as a point of connection for network devices. The hub held the electronic equivalent of a correctly terminated bus cable in a 10BASE-T Ethernet network. Switches have taken the position of hubs. Human–machine interface (HMI): A computer or collection of controls that exists between a controller and a human operator in a distributed control system (DCS). The HMI is controlled by a human, who interacts with the controller. Hybrid cloud: A collection of public and private cloud resources linked together to achieve a certain goal. There is no obvious dividing line between what is private and what is public in a hybrid cloud system. Hybrid topology: A combination of two distinct topologies. A hybrid of the star and bus topologies, for example, is a star-bus topology. Hypertext: A document that has been marked up such that a user can select words or images within it, click on them, and connect to other information. The foundation of the World Wide Web. HyperText Markup Language (HTML): An ASCII-based scripting language used to create hypertext texts such as those seen on the World Wide Web. Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP): Fast network file transfer protocol used on the World Wide Web. Hypertext Transfer Protocol over TLS (HTTPS): A secure version of HTTP in which hypertext is encrypted using Transport Layer Security (TLS) before being transmitted over the network. It is frequently used for Internet business transactions or when a secure connection is necessary. Also known as HTTP over SSL, this refers to the predecessor technology to TLS known as Secure Sockets Layer (SSL). See also Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and Secure Sockets Layer (SSL). Hypervisor: A layer of programming that builds, supports, and controls a virtual machine in virtualization. ICS server: A unit in a distributed control system (DCS) that can be used to handle global controller changes. ifconfig: Similar to ipconfig for Windows systems, this command-line program for Linux servers and workstations displays the machine's current TCP/IP setup. On most Linux systems, the newer command-line program ip has replaced ifconfig, while it remains the default on MacOS. Impedance: The degree of resistance on a wire to an electrical signal. It is used to determine the maximum quantity of data that a cable can handle. implicit deny any: A rule for access control lists that by default (implicitly) bans all access unless it is specifically permitted based on details such as IP addresses, e-mail addresses, or application type. A whitelist is a list of entries that are permitted to be entered. In-band management: Technology that allows managed devices, such as a switch or router, to be handled by any authorized host on the network. Inbound traffic: Describes the flow of packets with relation to a point of reference. Packets arriving from outside the network in relation to the overall network. Incident response: Reaction to any undesirable problems that occur within an organization and can be stopped, confined, and resolved without the use of outside resources. Incremental backup: Backs up all files with archive bits enabled, indicating that they have been altered since the last backup. After the files have been backed up, the archive bits are turned off. Independent Basic Service Set (IBSS): A basic unit of organization in wireless networks formed by two or more wireless nodes communicating in ad hoc mode. Independent Computing Architecture (ICA): Citrix created a remote access protocol. Although it was once the foundation of Windows Terminal Services, Microsoft now utilizes its own Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) for the same function. Industrial control system (ICS): A system that monitors and regulates machinery in a factory or chemical plant, or even a huge HVAC system in an office building. Infrastructure as a service (IaaS): A cloud service model that offers ondemand access to infrastructure such as servers, switches, and routers for resource-based fees. Virtualization is used by large-scale, worldwide IaaS providers to reduce idle hardware, defend against data loss and downtime, and adapt to spikes in demand. Infrastructure as code (IaC): An automation concept that defines the infrastructure (servers and network components) required by an application or service in configuration files or scripts in such a way that identical copies of the required infrastructure can be easily created. Infrastructure mode: Wireless networks in this mode use one or more wireless access points to connect wireless network nodes centrally. This layout is analogous to a wired network's star topology. Inheritance: A user permissions assignment mechanism in which folder permissions trickle downhill into subfolders. Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE): An international professional organization for electrical and electronics engineering and associated areas. Develops networking standards on a regular basis, such as the IEEE 802 family of LAN standards. Integrity: Keeping data from being modified or deleted without permission. In most networks, integrity is maintained primarily by tests that ensure data supplied to a recipient is unmodified when it arrives at the destination host. . Interface monitor: A program that monitors network traffic by tracking the bandwidth and utilization of one or more interfaces on one or more devices. interframe gap (IFG) : A brief, specified silence that was originally designed for CSMA/CD but is now also used in CSMA/CA. Intermediate distribution frame (IDF): The space where all of the horizontal runs from all of the work areas on a specific floor of a building meet. Intermediate System to Intermediate System (IS-IS): A link-state dynamic routing protocol similar to, but less well-known than, OSPF. IS-IS has always supported IPv6 and is the de facto standard for Internet service providers (ISPs). Internal firewall: The firewall that connects the perimeter network to the trusted network, which holds all of the organization's private servers and workstations. To safeguard internal servers and workstations, the internal firewall provides tight access control lists. Internal threats: Everything a network's own users do to cause difficulties on the network. Unintended file deletion, accidental damage to hardware devices or cabling, malevolent users, and abuse of rights and permissions are all examples. Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA): The organization that was initially in charge of allocating public IP addresses. IANA no longer issues IP addresses directly, but it does monitor Autonomous System Number (ASN) assignment. IANA allocates IP address blocks to the five Regional Internet Registries (RIRs) and delegated the task of assigning individual addresses to the RIRs. Internet Connection Sharing (ICS): Using a single Internet connection, multiple computers can access the Internet at the same time. When you employ Internet connection sharing, you use a single public IP address to connect a whole LAN to the Internet. Also referred to as Internet sharing, Internet of Things (IoT): Billions of common objects that can connect with one another, primarily via the Internet. Smart household appliances, vehicles, video surveillance systems, and other devices fall into this category. Internet Protocol (IP) Layer 3 protocol responsible for logical addressing and routing packets across networks, including the Internet. It does not guarantee reliable delivery of packets across the network, leaving that task to higher-level protocols. IP has two versions, IPv4, and IPv6. Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4): The first version of the Internet Protocol was released in 1980. IPv4 is made up of a protocol, a header, and an address specification. Its 32-bit addresses are written as four groups of numbers ranging from 0 to 255, separated by a period (often called dotted decimal format). There can be no IPv4 addresses that are all 0s or all 255s. IPv4 addresses examples include 192.168.0.1 and 64.176.19.164. Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6): As the address-space restrictions of IPv4 became obvious, a second version of the Internet Protocol was developed. Despite the fact that standardization began in the 1990s, the transition from IPv4 to IPv6 is currently underway. Its 128-bit addresses are made up of eight sets of four hexadecimal digits, each with a value between 0000 and ffff and separated by a colon. There are no IP addresses that are all 0s or all ffffs. For instance, fe80:ba98:7654:3210:0800:200c:00cf:1234. Internet Small Computer System Interface (iSCSI): A protocol that allows the SCSI command set to be transferred from a client to an iSCSIbased storage system through a TCP/IP network. iSCSI is widely used in storage area network (SAN) systems. Intrusion detection system (IDS)/intrusion prevention system (IPS): An application that inspects incoming packets for active intrusions (typically operating on a dedicated IDS box). An IDS and an IPS vary in that an IPS can respond to an attack by restricting traffic, but an IDS can only inform a person or device of the attack. IP address: An application (typically operating on a dedicated IDS box) that inspects incoming packets for active intrusions. The difference between an IDS and an IPS is that an IPS can respond to an attack by restricting traffic, but an IDS can simply inform a person or device of the attack. IP addressing: The assignment of IP addresses to networks and hosts. IP camera: To send output to a network resource or destination, a stillframe or video camera with a network interface and TCP/IP transport protocols is used. IP exclusion range: A range of IP addresses that have been purposefully excluded from the pool of addresses that a DHCP server may assign to clients. IP helper: An IP helper address (also known as a UDP helper address) or a command for configuring IP helper addresses are two different things. An IP helper address defines an IP address on another subnet to which all UDP broadcasts are sent by a router. Most commonly used to allow a single DHCP server to serve several subnets, but it also allows broadcasts for protocols like as TFTP, Time Service, TACACS, DNS, NetBIOS, and others to be passed along. ipconfig: A Windows command-line application that displays the machine's current TCP/IP configuration, comparable to macOS's ifconfig and UNIX/ip. Linux's IPsec VPN: A virtual private networking solution that secures itself with IPsec tunneling. ISP (Internet service provider): An organization that provides Internet connection in some way, usually for a price. IT (information technology): The computer, electronic communications, and electronic commerce industries. Computers are used in IT to create, exchange, and process many sorts of data. Java: Sun Microsystems' (now Oracle's) network-oriented programming language, which is often used for building programs that can be downloaded and run directly from the Internet. Web pages can feature animations, calculators, and other fancy tricks by using little Java programs (called applets). Jitter: A delay in transmitting all of the frames in a message; caused by too many devices on a network. Jumbo frames: Frames (often 9000 bytes in length, though anything over 1500 bytes qualifies) that allow massive data transfers easier and more efficient than using the regular frame size. Kerberos: An open authentication standard best recognized as the authentication protocol used in Windows Domains. Key Distribution Center (KDC): System for granting Kerberos authentication. The KDC is where secret keys for users and services are kept. Key fob: Small device that fits easily in a pocket or handbag or can be attached to a key ring. This gadget is used to identify the person who owns it in order to provide or refuse access to resources such as electronic doors. Key pair: In asymmetric-key encryption systems, two keys are generated, one public and one private. Keypad: The device that allows an alphanumeric code or password issued to a specific individual for a specific asset to be input. Krone LSA-PLUS (Krone): The Krone Group (a German telecommunications corporation) developed a proprietary connector in the 1970s as an alternative to the 110 punchdown block. Krone connectors allow for both networking and audio connectivity. Last mile: A telephone system's connection between a central office and individual users. Layer: A collection of connected tasks involving the exchange of information. Also, a specific level of the OSI seven-layer model, such as the Physical layer, Data Link layer, and so on. Layer 2 switch: Any device that filters and forwards frames based on the transmitting and receiving machines' MAC addresses. What is commonly referred to as a "switch" is actually a "Layer 2 switch." Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol (L2TP): A VPN protocol that may be used on practically any connection by combining Cisco's L2F and Microsoft's PPTP tunneling techniques. Although LT2P does not support authentication or encryption, it is frequently used in conjunction with IPsec to offer security. Layer 3 switch: A switch with the ability to route packets (it filters and forwards data packets based on the IP addresses of the sending and receiving machines). LC connector: A duplex small form factor (SFF) fiber connector that accepts two fiber wires. LED (light emitting diode): When a current is delivered to a solid-state device, photons at luminous frequencies are emitted. Legacy mode: When a current is delivered to a solid-state device, it releases photons at luminous frequencies. Legal hold: The procedure through which an organization saves and organizes data in anticipation of or in response to a pending legal issue. Light leakage: Interference created by bending a fiber-optic cable beyond its maximum bend radius. The cladding allows light to pass through, causing signal distortion and loss. Light meter: Technicians use an optical power meter to calculate the quantity of light lost due to light leakage in a fiber connection. Lights-out management (LOM): Special "computer within a computer" features added into better servers that allow you to access a server even when it is turned off. Lightweight Access Point Protocol (LWAPP): In wireless networks, this protocol facilitates interoperability between thin and thick clients as well as WAPs. Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP): A protocol for querying and changing a network database. By default, LDAP utilizes TCP port 389. Lightweight Extensible Authentication Protocol (LEAP): Cisco wireless products nearly entirely use a proprietary EAP authentication method. LEAP is an intriguing blend of MS-CHAP authentication and RADIUS server authentication. Link aggregation: Using many NICs in parallel to boost bandwidth in smaller increments. Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP): Certain IEEE features and choices for automating the negotiation, management, load balancing, and failure modes of aggregated ports are specified. Link light: An LED on NICs, routers, and switches that illuminates to indicate a successful connection between the devices. On the CISM exam, link lights are referred to as light-emitting diode (LED) status indicators. Link state: A dynamic routing protocol that simply notifies changes to routing tables rather than complete routing tables. In comparison, consider distance vector routing protocols. OSPF and IS-IS are two examples of linkstate routing protocols. See also distance vector. Link status: A network analyzer reports on the quality of a connection between two systems. Link-local address: The address that an IPv6-enabled machine assigns to itself upon launching. A link-local address's initial 64 bits are always fe80::/64. On a local network, link-local addresses are used to communicate. Linux: UNIX-inspired open source operating system family. Cloud infrastructure, embedded systems, enterprise servers, and mobile devices are all prominent applications. Listening port: A port that accepts incoming IP packets and forwards them to the program that opened the port. Load balancing: The practice of combining numerous servers to appear as a single server, distributing processing and meeting bandwidth requirements. Local: The computer(s), server(s), and/or LAN that a user is physically using or that are in the same room, building, or subnet that can span many buildings. Local area network (LAN): A network that usually (but not always) belongs to a single household or organization and covers a small area (anything from two devices in an apartment up to thousands of devices on a multi-building school or business campus). Local authentication: Using a password database maintained on the system to authenticate a user account (as opposed to on a remote authentication server). Log management: The practice of ensuring sufficient protection and upkeep for log files in order to keep them structured and safe. Logic bomb: When certain conditions are satisfied, code written with malevolent intent is executed. Logical address: A programmable network address (such as an IP address), as opposed to a physical address burned into ROM. Logical addressing: In contrast to physical addressing, subnetting is the technique of allocating ordered blocks of logically related network addresses to build smaller manageable networks. One example of logical addressing is IP addresses. Logical Link Control (LLC): The NIC component that communicates with the operating system, frames outbound data going "down" from the upper levels of software, and generates the FCS on each frame. The LLC also handles incoming frames, processing those directed to the NIC and deleting those addressed to other network machines. Logical network diagram: A document that lists the broadcast domains and individual IP addresses for all network devices. Only the most crucial switches and routers are displayed. Logical topology: A network topology established by signal routes rather than actual wire structure. Long Term Evolution (LTE): A wireless communication standard having download speeds of up to 300 Mbps and upload speeds of up to 75 Mbps. LTE is promoted as a fourth generation (fourth generation) cellular technology. Looking glass site: A server or Web site that enables technicians from outside of a network to inspect data or run diagnostic tools on that network. A technician may use their ISP's looking glass to troubleshoot a routing issue. Loopback plug: For physical loopback testing, a network connector connects back into itself. Loopback test: A test that sends data from a NIC and checks to see if it is received. Versions of software that do not examine the physical port are frequently included in the device's own diagnostics. Hardware or physical loopback testing involving the port necessitate the use of a loopback plug. MAC (media access control) address: Each network card has its own 48bit address. To help ensure that each address is unique, IEEE assigns blocks of possible addresses to various NIC manufacturers. The OSI seven-layer model's Data Link layer locates machines using MAC addresses. MAC address filtering: A method of restricting wireless network access based on the physical addresses of wireless NICs. MAC-48: A network interface card's distinct 48-bit address. The MAC address is also known as the EUI-48. Macro: Programming within an application that allows users to manipulate various aspects of it (generally to handle repetitive tasks). Also, any malware that uses application macros to replicate and activate itself. Mailbox: On an e-mail server, a special holding area that separates out email for each user. Main distribution frame (MDF): A building room that houses the demarc, telephone cross-connects, and LAN cross-connects. Maintenance window: The amount of time required to implement and thoroughly test a network change. Malicious user: A user who deliberately attempts to gain access to, steal from, or damage resources. Malware: Any program or code (macro, script, etc.) that is designed to perform an action on a system or network that you do not want to occur. Malware types include spyware, rootkits, worms, and ransomware. Managed device (SNMP): A managed network component. Managed devices send data to an SNMP manager for processing. Managed network: The SNMP protocol monitors a network, which includes SNMP managed devices, management information base (MIB) items, and an SNMP manager (s). Mandatory access control (MAC): A security model in which each resource is assigned a label indicating its level of security. If the user does not meet that level of security, they are denied access. Maximum transmission unit (MTU): In a communications protocol, such as Ethernet, this specifies the largest size of a data unit. MD5 (Message-Digest Algorithm Version 5): An older hashing function that has been cracked and should have been replaced by now, particularly in a security context. Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF): A factor that is typically applied to a hardware component and represents the manufacturer's best guess (based on historical data) as to how much time will pass between major component failures. Mean Time To Failure (MTTF): Indicates how long a device is expected to be operational. Only a single, definitive failure will occur in MTTF, necessitating the device's replacement rather than repair. Media Access Control (MAC): The portion of a NIC responsible for preparing outgoing frames, processing incoming frames, and controlling the physical layer interface. The MAC is in charge of addressing outgoing frames and validating the length and FCS of incoming frames. Media Access Control (MAC) address table: Every switch keeps a database that lists the MAC address and port of each connected device. Media Gateway Control Protocol (MGCP): A protocol intended to serve as a complete VoIP or video presentation connection and session controller. TCP ports 2427 and 2727 are used by MGCP. medianet: A network of dispersed routers and servers that provides adequate bandwidth for video teleconferencing (VTC) through quality of service (QoS) and other tools. mega: A prefix that usually represents the binary number 1,048,576. One megabyte is equal to 1,048,576 bytes. However, one megahertz equals one million hertz. Memorandum of understanding (MOU): In situations where a legal contract is not appropriate, a document that defines an agreement between two parties. Mesh topology: Each computer in a network has a direct or indirect connection to every other computer in the network. Any node on the network has the ability to forward traffic to other nodes. Popular in many wireless networks, including cellular. Metasploit: A tool that allows a penetration tester to use a large library of exploits and payloads while also tweaking them for specific penetrations. Metropolitan area network (MAN): Multiple computers connected within the same city via cabling, radio, leased phone lines, or infrared. The Chattanooga Gig, a gigabit network available to all citizens in Tennessee, is an excellent example of a MAN. Mixed mode: High-throughput, or 802.11a-ht/802.11g-ht, is one of three modes used with 802.11n wireless networks in which the wireless access point (WAP) sends special packets that support older standards while also improving their speed via 802. Model: A streamlined representation of a real-world object or process. In networking, models represent the logical tasks and subtasks required to perform network communication. Modem (modulator-demodulator): A device that converts both digital bit streams and incoming analog signals into digital signals (modulation) (demodulation). Typically used to connect telephone lines and computers. Modulation techniques: The various analog and digital multiplexing and demultiplexing technologies and protocols. Motion detection system: Some video surveillance systems have a feature that starts and stops recordings based on actions captured by the camera (s). Mounting bracket: In cable installations, a bracket that serves as a holder for a faceplate. MS-CHAP: Microsoft's dominant CHAP protocol variant employs a slightly more advanced encryption protocol. Multicast addresses: A collection of IP addresses designated for one-tomany communication, such as streaming video conferencing. Multifactor authentication (MFA) : A type of authentication in which a user must prove his or her identity using two or more factors. Multifactor authentication methods include knowledge factors (such as passwords or pin numbers), possession factors (such as a badge or smart card), and inherence factors (like fingerprints or voice). Multimode: A fiber-optic cable with a large core diameter that can support multiple modes of propagation. The large diameter simplifies connections but has distance implications. multipathing: An availability solution in which multiple connections or paths between a server and SAN are maintained to ensure continued availability if one connection fails. Multiplexer: A device that combines data from multiple input channels into a single output channel. Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS): A router feature that labels specific data in order to use a desired connection. It can be used with any type of packet switching (including Ethernet) to force specific types of data to use a specific path. Multisource agreement (MSA): A document that describes the compatibility of network hardware from various manufacturers. Multitenancy: The ability to support multiple customers concurrently on the same infrastructure. Customers with small computing needs can use multitenancy to pay only for what they need in exchange for sharing the same infrastructure as other customers. There is a risk that those customers will monopolize shared resources or compromise the infrastructure (by accident or on purpose). Name resolution: A method for locating another computer on a network in order to establish a session. All network protocols resolve names by utilizing some form of name server. Name server: DNS servers that store the actual name and IP DNS records in a database known as a zone. NAT translation table: A NAT router's special database that stores destination IP addresses and ephemeral source ports from outgoing packets and compares them to returning packets. Internal sockets are also mapped to their external counterparts in a NAT translation table. NAT64: A network traversal mechanism that attaches the bytes of an IPv4 address to the end of an IPv6 address. Native VLAN: The VLAN assigned to all frames that enter a switch trunk port without 802.1Q tags. Furthermore, any frames leaving the trunk port that are part of the native VLAN will not receive an 802.1Q tag. Neighbor advertisement: In response to a multicast neighbor solicitation packet, an IPv6 packet is sent informing the requesting system of the MAC address of the system that was solicited. Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP): IPv6 protocol that performs the same functions as ARP in IPv4 and is involved in features like SLAAC. It is made up of five different types of ICMP control messages: neighbor solicitation, neighbor advertisement, router solicitation, router advertisement, and redirect. NetBEUI (NetBIOS Extended User Interface): Microsoft's first networking protocol, intended for use with NetBIOS. TCP/IP has long rendered NetBEUI obsolete. Routing was not supported by NetBEUI. NetBIOS (Network Basic Input/Output System): A protocol that operates at the OSI seven-layer model's Session layer. This protocol establishes and manages connections based on the computer names involved. NetBIOS over TCP/IP (NetBT): A protocol developed by Microsoft that allows NetBIOS naming information to be transported over TCP/IP networks. As a result, Microsoft naming services can operate on a TCP/IP network without requiring DNS services. NetFlow collector: NetFlow component process that captures and saves data from the cache of a NetFlow-enabled device for future NetFlow analysis. netstat: A command-line utility for inspecting the open TCP/IP connections on a given host. It was once universal, but in Linux, it has been replaced by ss. Network: A grouping of two or more devices linked together by telephone lines, coaxial cables, satellite links, radio, and/or some other form of communication. A computer network is a collection of computers that are linked and communicate with one another for a common goal. Computer networks enable "people and organization" networks, which connect users who have a common goal for communicating. Network Access Control (NAC): Control over information, people, access, machines, and everything in between. Network access policy: Rules governing who can access the network, how it can be accessed, and what network resources can be used. Network address translation (NAT): A method of converting an IP address from one system to another before sending it to a larger network. A NAT program that runs on a system or a router implements NAT. A network that employs NAT assigns private IP addresses to the network's systems. The system running the NAT software has two interfaces, one to the network and one to the larger network. Network appliance: Feature-rich network box that includes routing, network address translation (NAT), switching, intrusion detection and prevention systems, a firewall, and other processes. Network Attached Storage (NAS): A dedicated file server with its own file system that typically employs hardware and software designed for file serving and storage. Network design: The process of gathering and planning the layout of the equipment required to build a network. Network Function Virtualization (NFV): A network architecture that automates and orchestrates network management using infrastructure-as-code (IaC) principles. Network Function Virtualization Infrastructure (NFVI): The foundation of network function virtualization hardware (such as generic servers and switches) and software (such as hypervisors and controllers) (NFV). Network interface card (NIC): Traditionally, an expansion card that allows a PC to physically connect to a network. Modern computers have built-in NICs that eliminate the need for physical cards, but the term "NIC" is still widely used. Network map: A highly detailed representation of a network, right down to individual computers. A network map displays IP addresses, ports, protocols, and other information. Network performance baseline: Under normal circumstances, network performance and access patterns are as follows. A network performance baseline, which can be obtained through continuous performance monitoring or periodic benchmarks, is used to assist in network troubleshooting. Network protocol: Every network-capable operating system contains special software that acts to generate unique identifiers for each system. It also generates a set of communication rules for issues such as dealing with data that has been divided into multiple packets and dealing with routers. TCP/IP is the most widely used network protocol suite today. Network segmentation: Separating network assets through various means, such as VLANs or a DMZ, to protect against malicious actor access. Network technology: Computer-to-computer link creation and operation techniques, components, and practices. Network threat: Any number of things that have one thing in common: the ability to harm network data, machines, or users. Network topology: The manner in which cables and other pieces of hardware are connected to one another. Network-based anti-malware: A single source server that contains up-to- date anti-malware software. That server's software can be accessed and run by multiple systems. The single site makes it easier to update and manage the software than anti-malware installed on individual systems. Network-based firewall: A firewall, which may be implemented in a gateway router or as a proxy server, must inspect all network traffic before it is allowed or blocked. Next-Generation firewall (NGFW): Network security device that operates at multiple layers of the OSI model to filter traffic that a traditional firewall cannot. Nmap: A popular open-source network scanner that uses packets and responses to scan a network and create a map of hosts and services. As a vulnerability scanner, it is frequently used. Node: A network member or a point at which one or more functional units connect transmission lines. Noise: Unwanted signals that contain no useful information and are frequently capable of introducing errors into the communication process. Non-persistent agent: Software used in posture assessment that is not kept in client station memory. It is executed prior to login and may remain resident in client RAM during the login session, but it is removed when the login or session is complete. The security characteristics are presented to the access control server, which decides whether to allow, deny, or redirect the connection. Normal backup: A complete backup of all selected files on a system. After the backup, this type of backup disables the archive bit. North-south traffic: Data traffic entering and leaving a data center. Edge routers, edge firewalls, and load balancers are examples of network equipment seen in north-south traffic. nslookup: A command-line utility for manually querying DNS servers for specific entries. When a technician has to check to see if a DNS record exists and confirm its value. NTFS (NT File System): A hard disk file system that supports object-level security, lengthy filenames, compression, and encryption. NTFS 4.0 was introduced with Windows NT 4.0. Later versions of Windows continue to upgrade NTFS. NTFS permissions: Groupings of what Microsoft refers to as special permissions, which include names like Execute, Read, and Write and grant or deny users access to files. ntpdc: Command that enters the NTP server into interactive mode so that queries can be submitted. OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer): Contrary to its name, does not develop original hardware, but rather acquires components from manufacturers and assembles them into systems under its own brand name. Dell, Inc. and Gateway, Inc., for example, are mostly OEMs. Apple, Inc. is not an OEM because it makes the majority of the components for its own Mac-branded laptops. offboarding: The process of ensuring that mobile devices leaving the organization's control do not include any proprietary software or data. Offsite: A phrase that refers to resources that are held and maintained elsewhere other than the primary office or site. Servers and data backups are two examples of offshore resources. Ohm rating: Impedance of a cable or an electrical component measured electronically. Omnidirectional antenna: Most WAPs use technology that sends wireless signals in all directions equally. Onboarding: The process of ensuring that new mobile devices introduced into an organization's infrastructure are secure and safe to use. On-path attack: Historically referred to as a man-in-the-middle attack. An attacker listens in on communications between two systems, intercepting content assumed to be exclusive to those systems, reading or, in some situations, modifying the data, and then sending it on. Open Shortest Path First (OSPF): An IP network inner gateway routing protocol based on the shortest path first or link state algorithm. Open source: Applications and operating systems that provide access to their source code, allowing developers to readily adapt applications and operating systems to match their individual requirements. Open Systems Interconnection (OSI): The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) defines a set of protocols that implements the OSI seven-layer model for network communications between computers. OpenSSH: A set of secure applications created by the OpenBSD organization to address Secure Shell's (SSH) issue of only allowing one session per tunnel. Operating system (OS): A collection of system software that maintains a computer's hardware and software resources and serves as an interface between the machine and the user. Microsoft Windows, Apple macOS, and Manjaro Linux are a few examples. Operator: A human who manages computer-controlled resources using a human-machine interface in a distributed control system. Optical Carrier (OC): Specification used to denote the optical data carrying capacity (in Mbps) of fiber-optic cables in SONET networks. The OC standard is a set of rising speeds intended to fulfill the needs of medium-tolarge enterprises. SONET creates OCs ranging from 51.8 Mbps (OC-1) to 39.8 Gbps (OC-768). Optical Time-Domain Reflectometer (OTDR): Fiber-optic cable tester that determines cable continuity and provides the location of cable breaks. Orchestration: A higher level of automation in which shorter sequences of smaller automated tasks are composed. These sequences (also known as pipelines, processes, or workflows) better illustrate what the corporation or its people are attempting to do. Also, music arrangement for several instruments. Organizationally Unique Identifier (OUI): The first 24 bits of a MAC address, assigned by the IEEE to the NIC manufacturer. Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiplexing (OFDM) : A spreadspectrum broadcasting system that combines DSSS's many frequencies with the hopping capability of FHSS. Oscilloscope: A device that provides a graphical or visual representation of signal levels over time. Outbound traffic: Describes the flow of packets with relation to a point of reference. Packets leaving the network from within it, in relation to the overall network. Out-of-band management: Connecting to and administering a controlled device, such as a switch or router that does not use a typical networkconnected host as the administrative console. Out-of-band administration is demonstrated using a computer attached to a switch's console connection. Overlay tunnel: Allows two IPv6 networks to communicate over an IPv4 network by enclosing IPv6 packets within IPv4 headers, conveying them across the IPv4 network, and then decapsulating the IPv6 payload. Packet: A fundamental component of network communication. A collection of bits with a set maximum size and well-defined format that are switched and transmitted as a whole via a network. Packet analyzer: A program that reads packet sniffer capture files and analyzes them based on monitoring requirements. Packet filtering: Any incoming or outgoing packet from a specific IP address or range of IP addresses is blocked by this approach. Passive optical network (PON): A fiber architecture in which a single fiber connects to the neighborhood switch and then separate fiber travels to each final destination. Password Authentication Protocol (PAP): Because all passwords are sent in cleartext, this is the least secure method of authentication. Patch antenna: A flat, plate-shaped antenna that generates a half-sphere beam and is used for local broadcasting. Patch bay: A dedicated A/V connection block (instead of twisted pair and fiber network connections). Patch management: The process of updating operating systems and apps on a regular basis in order to avoid security issues. Patch panel: A panel in the equipment room that contains a row of female connections (ports) that terminate the horizontal cabling. Patch panels help with cabling organizing and protect horizontal cabling. pathping: A command-line utility that combines the functionality of the ping and tracert/traceroute commands. Payload: The fundamental data that is encased in a frame or other protocol data unit (PDU) and transferred from one network device to another. Penetration testing (pen testing): An authorized network hacking procedure that detects and exploits real-world network security flaws and publishes the results. Permissions: Sets of properties assigned to individuals and groups by network administrators that define what they can do with resources. Persistent agent: A small scanning application in network access control systems that, once placed on a computer, remains installed and runs every time the computer boots up. Composed of modules that do an exhaustive inventory of every security-related element in the computer. Persistent connection: A link to a shared folder or drive that the machine reconnects to immediately upon logon. Personal area network (PAN): Bluetooth devices, such as smartphones, tablets, printers, keyboards, mouse, and so on, form a network. Phishing: A social engineering approach in which the attacker pretends as a trustworthy source and attempts to persuade the victim to behave on the basis of a false assumption (usually communicated via e-mail, phone, or SMS). Typically, a successful attack collects confidential information or inserts malware into the network. Physical address: An address written into a NIC's ROM chip. A physical address is an example of a MAC address. Physical network diagram: A document that lists all of the physical network connections. Each connection's cabling type, protocol, and speed are also given. Ping: A brief ICMP message issued to determine the presence and response of another system. A command-line utility that uses these messages to determine the "up/down" status of an IP-addressed host is also available. Ping –6: A command-line utility for determining the "up/down" state of an IP address. When using the Windows version of ping, the -6 switch specifies that the host under test has an IPv6 address. Plaintext: Describes the data that has been sent through a cipher (even if it is already encrypted). The encrypted ciphertext is produced by passing plaintext through a cipher algorithm with a key. Platform as a Service (PaaS): A cloud service architecture that provides a complete deployment and administration system that includes all of the tools required to operate and maintain a Web application. Plenum: A space between the false ceiling of a building and the floor above it. This is where the majority of network wiring is placed. Plenum is also a network cabling fire rating. Plenum-rated cable: When burned, this network cable type does not produce significant smoke or harmful smells. Point Coordination Function (PCF): A collision avoidance strategy defined by the 802.11 standard but yet to be implemented. Point-to-multipoint topology: A network topology in which one device communicates with more than one other device. Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP): A protocol that allows two devices to connect, authenticate using a username and password, and negotiate the network protocol to use. Point-to-Point Protocol over Ethernet (PPPoE): A protocol that was developed to encapsulate PPP frames in Ethernet frames. DSL providers use this to force clients to log into their DSL connections rather than simply connecting automatically. Point-to-point topology: A network topology in which two computers are connected directly to each other without the use of any further connecting components such as hubs or switches. Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol (PPTP): A historical protocol used to establish a secure data communication between computers (a VPN). It has long been included in Windows, but it has fallen out of favor due to several security flaws. Polyvinyl chloride (PVC): A substance used on the outside of most wires for insulation and jacketing. A fire rating is also provided for a type of cable that has no major fire protection. Port (logical connection): In TCP/IP, 16-bit values ranging from 0 to 65535 are assigned to a specific TCP/IP process or application. Web servers, for example, use port 443 (HTTPS) to send Web pages to clients. The first 1024 ports are referred to as well-known ports. They have been pre-assigned and often pertain to long-running TCP/IP processes and apps. Port (physical connector): In general, the part of a computer that allows a peripheral device to interface with it, such as video, USB, serial, and network ports. The jacks found in computers, switches, routers, and network-enabled peripherals into which network cables are plugged in the context of networking. Port authentication: Many modern networking devices have a function that authenticates a connecting device at the point of connection. Port blocking: Preventing TCP segments or UDP datagrams from passing through any ports other than those specified by the system administrator. Port bonding: Logical connection of several redundant ports and cables between two network devices, such as a switch and a storage array. Port forwarding: Preventing IP packets from passing through any ports other than those specified by the system administrator. Port mirroring: Many modern switches have the ability to mirror data from any or all physical ports on the switch to a single physical port. This is useful in any case where an administrator wants to inspect packets coming to or from certain computers. Port number: When connecting to a TCP/IP host, this number is used to identify the requested service (such as SMTP or FTP). Server port numbers such as 80 (HTTP), 21 (FTP), 25 (SMTP), 53 (DNS), and 67 are examples (DHCP). Power distribution unit (PDU): A series of rack-mounted outlets for devices installed in the rack. Connected to the uninterruptible power supply of the rack (UPS). Power generator: Backup generator that provides power redundancy in a data center or equipment room by burning petroleum fuel to supply energy if the main power goes out. Power over Ethernet (PoE): A standard that allows wireless access points (WAPs) to get electricity from the same Ethernet wires that carry data. Power redundancy: In the case the primary power fails, this serves as a backup. An uninterruptible power supply is the most prevalent type of redundant power source (UPS). Preamble: A frame is always preceded by a 7-byte series of alternating ones and zeroes, followed by a 1-byte start frame delimiter. The preamble allows a receiving NIC to detect the arrival of a frame and determine where the frame begins. Prefix delegation: A configuration of an IPv6 router that allows it to request an IPv6 address block from an upstream source and then distribute it to local clients. Primary name server: The name server is the location where records are added, deleted, and changed. In a zone transfer, the primary name server transmits copies of this zone file to secondary name servers. Private cloud: Software, platforms, and infrastructure owned and operated by an organization for internal usage. Private direct connections: Links between a company's network and a cloud provider. A private direct connection never uses the public Internet; instead, it uses a private line between an organization's data center and a cloud provider. Private IP addresses: Internal network IP address groups; Internet routers block these addresses, such as 10.x.x.x /8, 172.(16-31).x.x /16, and 192.168. (0-255).x /24. Program: A set of behaviors or instructions that a machine can understand and execute. It means to develop, write, and test such instructions when used as a verb. Programmable logic controller (PLC): A computer that controls a machine by following a set of predefined processes. Promiscuous mode: A NIC operation mode in which the NIC processes any frames it finds on the cable, regardless of the destination address. Prompt: An operating system or software character or message that indicates that it is ready to take input. Protected Extensible Authentication Protocol (PEAP): A password-based authentication system based on MS-CHAPv2 with the addition of an encrypted TLS tunnel comparable to EAP-TLS. Protocol: An agreement that defines the methods for exchanging information between collaborating entities; often includes how much information is to be sent, how frequently it is to be delivered, how to recover from transmission mistakes, and who is to receive the information. Protocol analyzer: A tool that monitors the many protocols that run at different layers of a network and can provide Application, Session, Network, and Data Link layer information on every frame that passes through it. Protocol data unit (PDU): A single information unit made up of protocol control information and some form of data. Different PDUs are used in different layers of the OSI model. A layer 2 PDU, for example, is known as a frame, whereas a layer 3 PDU is known as a packet. Protocol stack: The software that runs the protocol suite on a specific operating system. Protocol suite: A collection of protocols that are often used in conjunction and operate at various levels of the OSI seven-layer model. Proximity reader: Sensor that detects and reads tokens that come into contact with it. The polled information is used to determine the token holder's access level. Proxy ARP: The process of making faraway computers behave as if they are on the same LAN as local computers. Proxy server: A device that retrieves Internet resources for a client without directly connecting that client to the Internet. Most proxy servers accept HTTP, FTP, IMAP, and SMTP requests. A copy of the requested resource is frequently cached or stored by the proxy server for subsequent use. Public cloud: Software, platforms, and infrastructure made available to the broader public via networks. Public-key cryptography: A type of encryption and decryption that employs two keys: a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption. Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI): The mechanism for creating and distributing digital certificates issued by reputable third-party organizations such as DigiCert, GoDaddy, or Sectigo. PVC-rated cable: A network cable that provides no specific fire protection; when burned, it emits considerable smoke and toxic aromas. Quad Small Form-Factor Pluggable (QSFP): In 40GbE networks, a bidirectional (BiDi) fiber-optic connector is employed. Quality of service (QoS): Policies that limit the amount of bandwidth that a protocol, PC, user, VLAN, or IP address may consume. Quarantine network: Safe network to which stations are directed that do not require or should not have access to protected resources. Raceway: Cable management device that attaches to walls, allowing for a far simpler, albeit less neat, installation than running cables through the walls. Rack diagram: A diagram that shows the make and model of each component on a rack, as well as details like firmware versions, date of purchase, upgrade history, and service history. Rack monitoring system: Sensors in an equipment closet or rack-mounted gear that may monitor and alarm when a power, temperature, or other environmental state is out of tolerance. Radio Guide (RG) rating: The US military devised ratings to give a fast reference for the many types of coaxial cables. Ransomware: Crypto-malware is malware that employs encryption to lock a user out of a machine. After the crypto-malware encrypts the computer, generally the boot drive, it informs the user that the system must be paid to be decrypted. Whether or whether the data is encrypted after payment is mostly determined on the threat actor's motivation. Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP): A protocol that describes the types of packets that are used on the Internet to transport speech or data from a server to clients. RTP is used by the vast majority of VoIP solutions available today. Recovery Point Objective (RPO): A maximum amount of lost data that an organization can tolerate if it must restore from a backup. Determines how frequently backups must be taken. Recovery Time Objective (RTO): The amount of time required to restore full functionality from the point at which the organization ceases to exist. Recursive lookup (DNS): When a client requests a kind of record associated with a FQDN, the DNS server performs the necessary effort to return the record. In contrast, in an iterative lookup, the client asks each server along the DNS hierarchy (beginning at the root) until it finds the authoritative DNS server, which returns the record. Reddit hug of death: When a tiny or lesser-known Web site is suddenly made prominent by a media reference, it experiences a large flood of visitors. Redundant Array of Independent [or inexpensive] Disks [or devices] (RAID): A method for developing a fault-tolerant storage system. There are six levels of RAID. Level 0 employs byte-level striping and does not support fault tolerance. Mirroring or duplexing is used at Level 1. Bit-level striping is used at Level 2. Level 3 keeps error-correcting data (such parity) on a separate disk and data striping on the remaining drives. Level 4 is the same as level 3 with block-level striping. Level 5 employs data striping at the block and parity levels. Reflection: A method for building a fault-tolerant storage system. RAID has six stages. Level 0 employs byte-level striping and has no fault tolerance. Level 1 employs mirroring or duplexing. Level 2 employs bit-level striping. Level 3 stores error-correcting information (such as parity) on a separate disk and data striping on the remaining drives. Level 4 combines level 3 with block-level striping. Level 5 employs block-level and parity data stripping. Regional Internet Registries (RIRs): Entities overseen by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). RIRs allocate IP addresses from blocks assigned to them by IANA. Registered Jack (RJ): A connection that is found at the termination of telephone and networking cables. Registered ports: The port numbers range from 1024 to 49151. IANA assigns these ports to anyone who wants to utilize them for their applications. Regulations: Rules of law or policy that control workplace behavior, such as what to do when a specific occurrence occurs. Remote access: The ability to access a computer from outside the building it is housed in. Remote access necessitates the use of communications technology, software, and physical connectivity. Remote Access Server (RAS): Refers to both the hardware (servers built to handle the specific strains of a large number of customers ringing in) and software components of a remote access solution (apps that integrate with the operating system to allow remote access to the network). Remote Installation Services (RIS): A utility included with Windows 2000 that may be used to launch either a scripted installation or the installation of an operating system image onto a PC. Remote terminal: A connection to a remote computer that allows you to control it as if you were sitting in front of it and logged in. All remote terminal programs necessitate the use of a server and a client. The server is the machine that will be managed. The client is the machine from which you control the server. Remote terminal unit (RTU): Has the same functions as a controller in a SCADA context, plus added autonomy to deal with connection loss. It is also intended to use some type of long-distance communication. Repeater: A device that accepts all frames on one Ethernet segment and recreates them on another Ethernet segment. Repeaters function at the OSI seven-layer model's Layer 1 (Physical). They do not check the integrity of the Layer 2 (Data Link) frame, hence poorly generated frames may be repeated. Bridges that do frame integrity checking before repeating a frame replaced them in the early 1980s. Resistance: The ability of a physical material to obstruct electron passage. It has traditionally been measured in ohms. Resolver cache: A cache that Windows DNS clients utilize to store DNS information. Resource (networking): Some equipment, software, or data that can be accessed via a network connection. Files on a fileserver, a shared printer directly connected to another workstation, an inventory tracking application located on local servers, and a remotely hosted e-mail server are just a few examples. Reverse lookup zone: A DNS option that converts IP addresses to FQDNs. In other words, it does the exact opposite of what DNS ordinarily does with forward lookup zones. Reverse proxy server: A networking solution that collects information from its related servers and distributes it to clients. The clients are unaware of the servers operating behind the scenes. The only machine with which they communicate is the reverse proxy server. RF emanation: The intentional or unintentional broadcast of radio frequencies. These broadcasts may originate from components designed to transmit RF, such as a Wi-Fi network card, or from unexpected sources, such as a motherboard or keyboard. These emanations could be detected and intercepted, posing a security risk. Risk management: The process by which businesses examine, protect, and recover from network threats and attacks. Rivest Cipher 4 (RC4): A symmetric-key streaming algorithm. Because of the numerous weaknesses revealed since its first implementation, it is no longer secure. RJ-11: Connector with four-wire UTP connections; commonly used in telephone lines. RJ-45: A connector with eight-wire UTP connections that is commonly encountered in network connections and is used for 10/100/1000BASE-T networking. Roaming: A procedure in which clients effortlessly switch wireless access point (WAP) connections based on which WAP provides the strongest signal in the broadcast area. Rogue access point (rogue AP) : In a computer network, an unauthorized wireless access point (WAP). A rogue access point could be the consequence of an assault or a well-meaning user bringing hardware from home. Rogue DHCP server: In a computer network, an unauthorized DHCP server is installed. The malicious DHCP server could be in an unlawful device installed by a well-intentioned user, or it could be in an on-path assault. Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): The most common file sharing authentication model establishes a user's access to a resource based on the roles the user performs in the network environment. This gives rise to the concept of group formation. In most networks, a group is nothing more than a name with well defined access to various resources. User accounts are classified into groups. ROM (read-only memory): Nonvolatile memory that can be read but not written to is referred to as nonvolatile memory. This means that ROM code and data cannot be damaged by unintentional erasure. Furthermore, ROM preserves its data even after power is disconnected, making it an ideal media for storing BIOS data or information such as scientific constants. Root directory: The directory that contains all other directories. Rootkit: A type of malware that takes advantage of very low-level operating system functions to hide itself from all but the most aggressive of antimalware tools. Route (command): A command to display and edit the local system’s routing table. Route redistribution: Occurs in a multiprotocol router that learns route information using one routing protocol and distributes it using another routing protocol. Router: A device that connects disparate networks and sends packets from one network to another based solely on the protocol's network address. An IP router, for example, solely considers the IP network ID. Routers function at the OSI seven-layer model's Layer 3 (Network). Router advertisement (IPv6): Response of a router to a client's router solicitation, also sent at regular intervals, providing the client with information to configure itself (prefix, prefix length, and more). Routing and Remote Access Service (RRAS): Remote access server for Windows that delivers VPN and dial-up services. Supported protocols include PPTP, L2TP, and L2TP/IPsec. Routing loop: When one or more routes through interconnected routers form a closed loop, the routers respond slowly and the packets go undelivered. Routing table: A list of networks and the next hop to connect to them. Routers route traffic from one network to the next. This table can be manually or automatically generated. RSA (Rivest, Shamir, Adleman): An asymmetric cryptography technique for encrypting / decrypting communications and generating digital signatures. SC connector: Fiber-optic connector for single-mode and multimode fiber. It is distinguished by its push-pull, snap mechanical linkage, dubbed "stick and click." Subscriber connector, standard connector, and Siemon connector are all terms for the same thing. Scanner: A gadget that detects changes in light and darkness. It allows the user to digitally import photographs, other tangible images, and text into the computer. Screened subnet: A subnet that is either lightly protected or unprotected and is located between an outer firewall and an organization's highly protected internal network. Screened subnets are mostly used to host public servers (such as Web servers). Traditionally referred to as a demilitarized zone (DMZ). Secondary name server: A domain's authoritative DNS server. A secondary name server, unlike a primary name server, cannot add, delete, or modify zones. It always receives all information from the primary name server in a process known as a zone transfer. Secure Copy Protocol (SCP): One of the first SSH-enabled programs to appear after SSH was introduced. SCP was one of the earliest protocols used to securely transfer data between two hosts and may have replaced FTP. SCP is functional, although it lacks functionality such as a directory listing. Secure Hash Algorithm (SHA): A well-known family of cryptographic hashing algorithms that includes SHA-1, SHA-2, and SHA-3. SHA-1 is no longer secure and should be avoided in all security contexts. Secure Shell (SSH): A terminal emulation application that mimics Telnet but encrypts the data. On the Internet, SSH has mostly supplanted Telnet. Secure Sockets Layer (SSL): Netscape developed a mechanism for protecting Web sites. Before the name was changed to TLS in 1999, the final version was 3.0. Security: Enhancing a network's resistance against unauthorized access or attack. Security considerations: Planning how to keep data safe from unauthorized access in network design and construction. Physical computer and network resource security are also taken into account. Security guard: Controlling access to physical resources such as buildings, secure rooms, and other physical assets is the responsibility of this person. Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) A two-part process that includes security event management (SEM), which monitors security occurrences in real time, and security information management (SIM), which reviews and analyzes monitoring log files using automatic and human translators. Security policy: A set of procedures that define the steps that employees should do to ensure the network's security. Segment (network): The bus cable to which the computers on an Ethernet network connected in the early days of Ethernet. In modern networks, a generic term for any subset of a network, such as a subnet or VLAN. It should not be confused with a TCP segment. Segmentation: The act of slicing requested data into chunks that will fit into a packet (and subsequently into the NIC's frame) on a TCP/IP network, arranging the packets for the benefit of the receiving system, and giving them to the NIC for sending. Separation of duties: A defense-in-depth strategy in which a single user cannot complete a specific job without the direct involvement or observation of another party. A server room, for example, requires at least two employees to be badged in at any given time. Server-based network: A network in which one or more systems operate as file, print, or application servers but do not serve as clients. Service level agreement (SLA): A contract between a consumer and a service provider that specifies the scope, quality, and terms of the service. Service Set Identifier (SSID): A contract between a consumer and a service provider that specifies the extent, quality, and terms of the service to be given. Services: Background programs in an operating system that perform grunt work behind the scenes that users do not need to deal with on a frequent basis. Session: A networking word for the logical stream of data that flows between two programs and is exchanged through a network. Many separate sessions may originate from a single network node. Session hijacking: Interception of a valid computer session in order to obtain authentication information. Session Initiation Protocol (SIP): A signaling protocol used to control voice and video calls over the internet. SIP vies with H.323 for VoIP supremacy. Set (SNMP): The PDU used by a network management station to instruct an agent to modify a management information base (MIB) object. Shell: The user interface of an operating system in general. A shell is the command processor that serves as the user's interface with the kernel. Shielded twisted pair (STP): A network cabling made up of pairs of wires twisted around each other at regular intervals. The twists function to reduce interference (also called crosstalk). The more turns there are, the less interference there is. The cable is shielded with metal to protect the wires from outside interference. Short circuit: Allows electricity to flow between two conductive elements that were not intended to interact. Short Message Service (SMS) alert: A proactive SMS text message issued in response to an SNMP managed device's out-of-tolerance state. Shoulder surfing: The technique of secretly observing people while they use any type of technology in order to steal passwords, PIN codes, or sensitive information. A tried-and-true social engineering tactic. Signal strength: A measure of how well your wireless gadget communicates with other devices. Signal-to-noise ratio (SNR): A measure of how much of a received broadcast is discernible signal and how much is noise. When constructing and debugging Wi-Fi networks, this tool can help you understand the quantity of interference (such as RFI). Signature (malware): A sequence of bits or bytes that is specific to a particular pathogen. Virus scanning software keeps a signature library and compares the contents of scanned files to this library to find infected files. Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP): The primary protocol for sending electronic mail over the Internet. TCP port 25 is used by SMTP. Simple Mail Transfer Protocol Secure (SMTPS): TCP port 587 is used to secure SMTP connection with TLS. SMTPS is not an SMTP extension or a proprietary protocol. Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP): A suite of protocols for communicating with network devices (switches, routers, and wireless access points) connected to a TCP/IP network. Used for network administration. Single point of failure: One component or system that, if it fails, will bring a process, workflow, or organization to a halt. Single sign-on (SSO): A one-time login to a gateway system performed by a client. This system, in turn, handles the client's authentication to any other connected systems to which the client has access. Site survey A method of informing wireless network design by mapping out the physical space in order to discover requirements, obstructions, and sources of interference. Site-to-site VPN: A VPN connection that uses two VPN concentrators to permanently connect two different LANs. slashdotting: When a tiny or lesser-known Web site is suddenly made prominent by a media reference, it experiences a large flood of visitors. Small Form Factor (SFF): A discussion of later-generation fiber-optic connectors that are substantially smaller than the first connector iterations. Small form-factor pluggable (SFP): A Cisco module that allows you to extend the functionality of its routers. Smart card: Authentication device (such as a credit card) that you plug into your PC or use on a door pad. Smart device: In lieu of typing a password, you insert a device (such as a credit card, USB key, etc.) into your PC. Smart jack: A network interface unit (NIU) that allows ISPs or phone providers to test for network issues such as disconnections and loopbacks. Smart locker: A wirelessly controlled locker that allows an organization to provide particular users temporary access. The lockers give a safe place to transfer equipment to a specific user, store stuff while users are away, or leave items for someone else to recover later. SMB (Server Message Block): Microsoft clients and servers utilize this protocol to share file and print resources. sneakernet: Putting a file on a portable medium and transporting it to another computer. Sniffer: A diagnostic application that can instruct a network interface card to operate in promiscuous mode. SNMP manager: Monitoring and management information base (MIB) items are monitored and managed using software and a station that connects with SNMP agents. snmpwalk: SNMP manager PDU that collects management information base (MIB) information from a MIB object and any of its subordinate objects in a tree-oriented structure. The snmpwalk command queries the object and then automatically queries any subordinated objects to the parent object being requested. Social engineering: Using or influencing employees within an organization to get unlawful access. Phishing and impersonation are two common socialengineering tactics. Socket: A port number, Layer 4 protocol, and IP address combination that uniquely identifies a connection. Socket pairs: Either pair is made up of two connected sockets, one at each end of a TCP/IP session between two hosts. Software: Data or programming instructions saved on a binary storage medium. Software as a Service (SaaS): A cloud service concept that offers centralized applications that may be accessed via a network. Software-Defined Networking (SDN): Programming that allows a master controller to regulate how network components transfer traffic through the network. In virtualization, this term is used. SOHO (small office/home office): Programming that allows a master controller to determine how network components will transfer traffic via the network. Used in virtualisation. SONET (Synchronous Optical Network): A fiber carrier standard used in the United States to connect fiber-optic transmission networks. SONET was first proposed in the mid-1980s and has now become an ANSI standard. SONET defines interface standards at the OSI seven-layer model's Physical layer. Spanning Tree Protocol (STP): A protocol that allows switches to automatically detect and prevent switching loops. Spectrum analyzer: A tool for detecting interference by scanning for radio frequency (RF) sources. Spine-and-leaf architecture: In a two-tiered mesh network, every spine switch links to every leaf switch in a data center architecture. Because traffic flows easily from spine to leaf to spine, regardless of how many spine or leaf switches are on the network, the mesh network eliminates the requirement for dedicated connections between spine backbone switches. Split pair: When signals on one pair of wires in a UTP connection interfere with signals on another pair of wires in the same cable, this circumstance arises. spoofing: A security risk in which an attacker makes data appear to have originated elsewhere, such as sending an e-mail with someone else's e-mail address in the sender field. Spyware: Any application that sends data about your system or your behavior via the Internet. SQL (Structured Query Language): A language developed by IBM that performs database queries using simple English-like sentences. SQL allows databases from many vendors to be queried using a common syntax. SRV record: A DNS record that links servers for specific protocols to a domain. SRV records define a specific service's host, port, protocol, and other characteristics. VoIP clients, for example, may easily locate a domain's associated SIP server. SSH File Transfer Protocol (SFTP): After many of the shortcomings of Secure Copy Protocol (SCP), such as the inability to see the files on the other computer, were found, a successor for FTP was created. Not to be confused with FTP over SSH, Simple File Transfer Protocol, or FTPS. SSID broadcast: A wireless access point feature that broadcasts the WAP's SSID to help wireless clients find and connect to it. Most WAPs broadcast their SSID by default. SSL VPN: A VPN that previously used SSL encryption but now employs TLS. SSL portal VPNs and SSL tunnel VPNs are the two most frequent types of SSL VPNs. Clients connect to the VPN server via a conventional Web browser in portal VPNs; in tunnel VPNs, they utilize a dedicated VPN client. Although SSL is no longer in use, the SSL VPN label has stuck. ST connector: Fiber-optic connector typically used with 2.5-mm singlemode fiber. It employs a push-on, twist-to-lock mechanical connection known colloquially as stick-and-twist, while ST actually stands for straight tip. Star topology: A network topology in which all machines in the network connect to a single point of connectivity. Star-bus topology: A mix of the star and bus topologies that use a physical star in which all nodes connect to a single wire point (such as a hub), as well as a logical bus that adheres to Ethernet standards. Fault tolerance is one advantage of a star-bus topology. Star-ring topology: A hybrid topology that employs both a physical star and a logical ring. The star-ring topology eventually lost market share to the more popular star-bus topology. Start Frame Delimiter (SFD): A one-byte segment of an Ethernet packet that comes after the preamble but before the Ethernet frame. Start Of Authority (SOA) record: A DNS record that specifies the primary name server for a domain. Also includes factors that determine how secondary name servers check for zone file updates, such as the serial number, which signals if the zone file needs to be updated. stateful filtering/stateful inspection: A filtering approach in which all packets are analyzed as a stream. Stateful devices can do more than just allow or block; they can detect when a stream is disturbed or packets become malformed and take appropriate action. Stateless (IPv6) : Describes a DHCPv6 server that just sends out information such as DNS server IP addresses and does not assign IPv6 addresses to clients. Stateless address auto configuration (SLAAC): A method for network clients to determine their own IPv6 addresses without the need of DHCP. Stateless filtering/stateless inspection: A filtering approach in which the filtering device examines each IP packet individually, looking for IP addresses and port numbers and blocking or permitting accordingly. Statement Of Work (SOW): A contract that specifies the services, products, and timeframes that the vendor must meet. Static addressing: The procedure of manually entering IP addresses into client computers. Static NAT (SNAT): A network address translation (NAT) method that assigns a single routable IP address to a single computer, allowing access to that machine from outside the network and vice versa. Static routes: Router routing table entries that have not been modified by any routing protocols. A router administrator must add, delete, or alter static routes. Dynamic routes are the inverse of static routes. Static routing: A router's usage of manually entered static routes to forward traffic to other networks. Storage: A device or media that can store data for later retrieval. Storage Area Network (SAN): A server that may expose a pool of hard disks across the network as any number of logical disks. Straight-through cable: UTP or STP cable segment in which the wire and pin assignments at one end match the wire and pin assignments at the other end. Straight-through cables are the connective opposite of crossover cables and are used to link hosts to switches or switches to routers. Stranded core: A cable that transmits signals using a bundle of small wire strands. Stranded core is not as good a conductor as solid core, but it will withstand heavy handling without breaking. Stream cipher: A method of encryption that encrypts a single bit at a time. When data comes in long streams, this method is popular (such as with older wireless networks or cell phones).
