Stripe set: A collection of two or more drives used for a striped volume. Structured cabling: The American National Standards Institute/Telecommunications Industry Association (ANSI/TIA) defines standards for grouping network cables for ease of maintenance and replacement. Subnet ID: An IP address portion that indicates bits common by all hosts on that network. Subnet mask: The value used in TCP/IP settings to split a host's IP address into two parts: network ID and host ID. subnetting: Taking a large block of IP addresses and dividing them into smaller units. Subscriber Identity Module (SIM) card: Small storage device used in cellular phones to identify the phone, enable network access, and store information such as contacts. Succession planning: The process of finding people who can temporarily take over certain jobs if the people in those positions are incapacitated or killed in an occurrence. Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition (SCADA): A system that has the fundamental components of a distributed control system (DCS), but is built for large-scale, distributed processes and functions, with the understanding that remote devices may or may not be in continuous communication with the central control. Switch: A multiport Layer 2 (Data Link) device that filters and forwards frames based on MAC addresses. Switch port protection: Several approaches for assisting modern switches in dealing with malicious software and other dangers. This category includes technologies such as flood guards. Switching loop: A circular path formed by connecting several switches in a circuit. Switches identify loops and disable the linked port using the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP). A bridge loop is also known as a bridging loop. Symmetric DSL (SDSL): Type of DSL connection that offers equal upload and download speeds and, in principle, rates of up to 15 Mbps, while the vast majority of ISPs offer packages ranging from 192 Kbps to 9 Mbps. Symmetric-key algorithm: Any encryption method that employs the usage of the same key for encryption and decryption. Syslog: In macOS and Linux, the system log collector collects logs. Auditing, performance monitoring, and troubleshooting are all possible applications. System life cycle: A typical beginning and end of computer components is described. Finally, dealing with such devices entails system life cycle rules and asset disposal. System log: A log file that keeps track of issues that affect the entire system, such as system services, device drivers, or configuration changes. Tamper detection: If the chassis is opened, this function of current server chassis will log in the motherboard's nonvolatile RAM (NVRAM). The log will reveal the date and time of the chassis intrusion. Alternatively, special stickers or zip ties that rupture when a gadget is opened. TCP segment: An IP packet's connection-oriented payload. TCP segments operate at the Transport layer. TCP three-way handshake: A three-packet exchange between TCP hosts to initiate and begin a data transfer session. The initiator initiates the communication with a SYN request. The target answers to the SYN request with a SYN response and an ACK. With an ACK, the initiator verifies receipt of the SYN-ACK. After this handshake, data transfer can commence. TCP/IP suite: The set of protocols and processes that enable TCP over IP communication over a network. Telecommunications room: A central location for computer or phone equipment, as well as centralized cabling. Typically, all cables from the remainder of the installation are routed to the telecommunications room. Telnet: A application that allows Internet users to log on to remote computers from their own host systems. Because of its lack of encryption, Telnet is no longer used. Temperature monitor: A device for maintaining an optimal temperature in a telecommunications room. TEMPEST: The NSA's security standard for combating radio frequency (RF) emission through the use of enclosures, shielding, and even paint. Terminal emulation: Software that allows a PC to communicate with another computer or network in the same way that a hardware terminal would. Ticket-Granting Ticket (TGT): In a Kerberos system, this is sent by an Authentication Server if the credentials given by the client match those in its database. The TGT is used by the client to obtain authorization from the Ticket-Granting Server for network resources. Time-domain reflectometer (TDR): Advanced cable tester that measures the length of cables as well as their continuity or discontinuity and locates any discontinuity caused by a bend, break, undesirable crimp, and so on. Time To Live (TTL): A field in an IP header that indicates the number of hops a packet can take before being rejected by a router. Toner: A tone locator (probe) and a tone generator are two devices that work together to trace cables by sending an electrical signal along a wire at a specific frequency. When the tone locator detects that frequency, it generates a sound. Also known as Fox and Hound. Top-level domain servers: A group of DNS servers located directly below the root servers that manage top-level domain names such as.com,.org,.net, and so on. Top-of-rack switching: An access switch implementation in which each equipment rack has one (or two for redundancy) Layer 2 switch at the top of the rack that connects to all of the systems on the rack. Top-of-rack switches live in the same rack as the servers, as opposed to switches that live in a separate rack. Topology: The pattern of interconnections between devices, nodes, and associated input and output stations in a communications system. Describes how computers connect to one another without respect for how they interact. tracert (also traceroute): A command-line utility for tracing the path that a packet traverses between two hosts. tracert –6 (also traceroute6): A command-line utility that examines the path from the station issuing the command to the destination host. The -6 switch in the command line indicates that the destination host has an IPv6 address. traceroute6 is a Linux command that runs a traceroute to a host with an IPv6 address. Traffic analysis: The process of obtaining knowledge from network traffic flows. Traffic shaping: Controlling the flow of packets into and out of the network based on packet type or other rules. Traffic spike: An unusual and generally dramatic surge in network traffic. Traffic spikes may be the consequence of routine organizational processes or an indicator of something more sinister. Trailer: The frame check sequence is a section of an Ethernet frame (FCS). Transceiver: Interchangeable network modules that allow a network device's media (and associated Ethernet standards) to be easily changed. Most commonly used to provide fiber-optic interfaces for switches, routers, and network interface cards (NICs). Transmission Control Protocol (TCP): Within the TCP/IP suite, a Layer 4 connection-oriented protocol. TCP ensures that all packets are accounted for and retransmitted if any are lost, resulting in a reliable communications channel across an unpredictable network. Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/IP): The United States Department of Defense created a series of communication protocols that allow disparate computers to share information via a network. TCP maintains data transfer reliability and accuracy whereas IP offers an address system and delivers packets between hosts. Transport Layer Security (TLS): TLS hosts employ public-key cryptography to securely negotiate a cipher and symmetric key across an unsecured network, and the symmetric key is then used to encrypt the remainder of the session. The historical SSL protocol's current name. Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP): A protocol that allows files to be transferred between servers and clients. Unlike FTP, TFTP does not require a user login. Devices that require an operating system but do not have a local hard disk (such as diskless workstations and routers) frequently use TFTP to download their operating systems. Trojan horse: A virus that disguises itself as a file with a valid purpose in order to trick a user into running it on purpose. A common example is a bogus antivirus application that installs a dangerous program under the pretence of safeguarding the computer. Trunk port: A switch port that is set to transfer all data between all switches in a LAN, independent of VLAN number. Tunnel broker: In IPv6, a service that generates the actual tunnel and (typically) provides you with a custom-made endpoint client to use, but more skilled users can often connect manually. Tunnel Information and Control (TIC) protocol: One of the protocols responsible for configuring and logging into IPv6 tunnels. Tunnel Setup Protocol (TSP): One of the protocols that establishes IPv6 tunnels and handles configuration and login. Twisted pair: Twisted pairs of cables are the most prevalent type of cabling used in networks. UTP (unshielded twisted pair) and STP (shielded twisted pair) are the two forms of twisted pair cable (shielded twisted pair). The twists serve to reduce interference, known as crosstalk; the more twists there are, the less crosstalk there is. Two-factor authentication: A method of security authentication that requires two independent ways of authentication, such as a physical token that prompts for a password when inserted. Also known as multifactor authentication (MFA). UC device: It is one of three components of a unified communication (UC) network that handles voice, video, and other services. UC gateway: It is one of three components of a unified communication (UC) network that adds extra services to an edge router. Ultra-physical contact (UPC) connector: A fiber-optic connector that physically connects two fiber-optic wires. The fibers within a UPC are thoroughly polished for a greater quality and improved junction integrity. Unencrypted channel: Unsecure communication between two hosts using cleartext data transmission. A Telnet connection is an unencrypted channel that is widely used. Unidirectional antenna: An antenna that transmits all of its energy in a single, rather limited direction. Similarly, its architecture restricts its capacity to receive signals that are not oriented in the desired direction. Unified communication (UC): A system that combines several network services into one. Examples include instant messaging (IM), phone service, and video conferencing. Unified threat management (UTM): A firewall that comes with a slew of other programs and utilities for detecting and preventing a wide range of threats. Intrusion detection systems, intrusion prevention systems, VPN portals, load balancers, and other threat mitigation devices are among these safeguards. Unified voice services: Completely self-contained Internet services that rely solely on software installed on computers and the microphone/speakers on the computers to deliver voice communications over the Internet. The cloud handles all linkages to the public switched telephone network (PSTN). Uniform resource locator (URL): An Internet address that specifies the kind and location of a resource. Almost every TCP/IP program makes use of URLs. Uninterruptible power supply (UPS): A gadget that provides continuous clean electricity to a computer system while the computer is turned on. It safeguards against power outages and sags. The term UPS is frequently used incorrectly to refer to a standby power supply or system (SPS). Unsecure protocol: An unsafe protocol that sends data between hosts in an unencrypted (cleartext) manner. If these packets between communicating hosts are intercepted, their data is entirely exposed and readable. Uplink port: A switch port that allows you to connect two switches using a straight-through wire. User Datagram Protocol (UDP): TCP/connectionless IP's protocol suite. It has less overhead and better performance than TCP, but it also has a higher mistake rate. In a TCP/IP network, fire-and-forget UDP datagrams perform a variety of crucial behind-the-scenes tasks. User profile: A set of settings that belongs to a specific user account and may follow the user regardless of which machine he or she logs on to. These options allow the user to adjust the environment and security settings. User-level security: A security system in which each user has an account and resource access is granted based on user identity. UTP coupler: A single-ended, passive connector with female connectors on both ends. When it is deemed unnecessary or undesirable to use a single, lengthy cable, UTP couplers are used to join two UTP cable segments together to obtain longer length. Very-high-bit-rate DSL (VDSL): The most recent DSL technology, with download and upload rates of up to 100 Mbps. Although VDSL was designed to operate on copper phone lines, several VDSL providers use fiber-optic infrastructure to extend effective range. Video surveillance: Remotely monitored visual systems such as IP cameras and closed-circuit televisions are used in security measures (CCTVs). Video teleconferencing (VTC): The traditional multicast-based presentation in which one presenter sends a video stream to any number of properly setup and authorized multicast clients. Virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI): Technologies for providing and managing virtual desktops that make use of virtual machines. When desktop VMs are centered on a smaller number of servers, VDI can give benefits such as flexible management. Virtual disk: Block-level storage offered by a storage area network (SAN) that acts as a physical, directly attached hard drive for the client computer. Virtual firewall: A firewall that is built in software within a virtual computer when installing a typical physical firewall would be difficult, costly, or impossible. Virtual IP (VIP) address: A single IP address that is shared by several systems. This is the one IP address that is typically issued to a home or organization that uses NAT to have numerous IP stations on the private side of the NAT router. First Hop Redundancy Protocol also makes use of virtual IP addresses (FHRP). Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN): A managed switch feature that allows a single switch to support several Layer 2 broadcast domains while also providing isolation between hosts on separate VLANs. Modern network performance and security rely on it. Virtual Machine (VM): A virtual computer that can be accessed via a program called a hypervisor or virtual machine monitor. A virtual machine runs within your actual operating system, allowing you to run two or more operating systems at the same time. Virtual Network Interface Card (vNIC): A software-based NIC that performs the same activities as a physical NIC and uses a software connection to transfer traffic from the physical NIC to the virtual one. Virtual PBX: Software that functions as a replacement for a physical PBX phone system. Virtual private network (VPN): A network setup that allows a remote user to connect to a private network using the Internet. VPNs use tunneling, an encryption technique that protects data from interception. Virtual router: A virtual machine router that is implemented in software. Because a virtual machine is scalable, it is simple to increase capacity to the router as needed. Virtual routers are simple to administer and highly scalable without the need for extra network hardware. Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP): FHRP open standard that enables high availability by combining several routers into a single virtual router with a single virtual IP address that clients use as a default gateway. Protocol for First Hop Redundancy (FHRP). Virtual switch: Layer 2 switching software that runs within a hypervisor and allows virtual machines (VMs) to communicate with one another without leaving the host system. Virtualization: In general, the process of running software (referred to as a hypervisor) on a host computer to produce a virtual machine (VM) that emulates (virtualizes) the hardware found on a real computer. A pattern in which existing components are replaced with software (virtual) equivalents that are nearly indistinguishable to any programs, devices, or users that interface with them. Virtualized Network Functions (VNFs): Firewalls, load balancers, and routers are examples of network functions that use network function virtualization technology (NFVI). Virtualized Network Function Components (VNFCs): Virtual machines (or containers) that can be linked together to form a VNF, such as a VPN concentrator or firewall. Virus: A program that can duplicate itself on a system without the user's knowledge. All viruses carry a payload that may or may not be malicious. To function, computer viruses often require the execution of a host file or application. Virus definition or data files: Allows virus prevention software to detect and remove viruses from your system. Virus shield: Anti-malware software that passively monitors a computer's activities, looking for viruses only when specific events occur, such as the execution of a program or the downloading of a file. VLAN hopping: Anti-malware software that passively monitors a computer's activities, looking for viruses only when particular events occur, such as a program running or a file being downloaded. VLAN pooling: A method for balancing wireless network clients with a single SSID. To avoid high volumes of broadcast traffic, clients are distributed across multiple VLANs. VLAN Trunking Protocol (VTP): Cisco's proprietary technique for automating VLAN syncing across switches. VoIP gateway: Interconnection point between a traditional switched telephone network and a VoIP service provider. VoIP PBX: A private branch exchange that replaces traditional switched telephone connections with VoIP. Voltage event recorder: By hooking into a power socket, it tracks voltage over time. A voltage quality recorder is another name for it. VPN concentrator: A server application that can handle a large number of VPN connections (L2TP, SSL VPN, etc.). Typically found as a component of a VPN-capable router. VPN tunnel: A secure Internet connection between a client and a server; the VPN tunnel allows the client to access remote resources as if they were local. Vulnerability: A vulnerability in an infrastructure that a threat actor could exploit. Vulnerability management: The continuing process of identifying and dealing with vulnerabilities. WAN (wide area network): A geographically distributed network formed by connecting numerous computers and LANs over vast distances, typically through the use of leased phone lines. There is no clear distinction between a WAN and a LAN. Warm site: A facility that contains all of the physical resources, computers, and network equipment required to recover from a primary site disaster. Because a warm site lacks current backup data, it may take a day or more to retrieve and install backups before business operations may resume. Wavelength: The distance that a laser pulse must travel before it completes its cyclical oscillation and begins to repeat. Colors can be loosely connected with wavelength, which is measured in nanometers. Web server: A server that uses the HTTP protocol and is frequently encrypted with TLS. Originally intended to provide only HTML Web sites, has since evolved into the backbone for practically all network-based applications. Web services: Applications and procedures that can be accessed remotely rather than locally on the client workstation. Web services include Webbased e-mail, network-shareable documents, spreadsheets, and databases, as well as a variety of other cloud-based applications. Well-known port numbers: Port numbers ranging from 0 to 1023 that are generally used by client applications to communicate with server applications in TCP/IP networks. Wi-Fi: The most extensively used wireless networking technology today. Only wireless devices that comply with the extended versions of the 802.11 standard—802.11a, b, g, n, ac, and ax—are certified as Wi-Fi. Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA): A wireless security protocol that fixes WEP's flaws and serves as an update. WPA adds security features such as dynamic encryption key generation (keys are issued per-user and persession), encryption key integrity checks, user authentication using the industry-standard Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP), and other sophisticated features that WEP lacks. WPA has being phased out in favor of the more secure WPA2. Wi-Fi Protected Access 2 (WPA2): The consumer name for the IEEE 802.11i standard, which replaces the WPA protocol. It employs the Advanced Encryption Standard algorithm, which makes it far more difficult to crack than its predecessor. Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 (WPA3): WPA3 is the wireless encryption protocol that will replace WPA2. Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE) is a Diffie-Hellman key exchange that creates unique encryption keys between each client and WAP. Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS): Connecting a wireless device to a WAP using an automated or semi-automatic approach. The procedure can be as simple as pressing a device button or pressing the button and then entering a PIN code. WPS is very susceptible to brute force attacks. Windows Defender Firewall: The firewall that has been included in Windows operating systems since Windows XP SP2; it was previously known as the Internet Connection Firewall (ICF), but was renamed in later versions of Windows. Windows domain: A collection of computers managed by a computer running the Windows Server operating system and the Active Directory Domain Controller role. Wire map: A copper cable test that examines not only for continuity but also that all wires on both ends of the cable connect to the correct location. A wire map will detect shorts and crossed wires as well. Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP): An early Wi-Fi security protocol that employs the RC4 encryption method. Due to serious security flaws, it is no longer in use. Wired/wireless considerations: When developing or updating networks, the design of structured cabling, assessing any wireless requirements, and arranging Internet access. Wireless Access Point (WAP): This device connects wireless network nodes to wired or wireless networks. Many WAPs are hybrid devices that serve as high-speed hubs, switches, bridges, and routers all in one. Wireless analyzer: Any gadget that discovers and records all wireless networks in the vicinity. A Wi-Fi analyzer is another name for it. Wireless bridge: Device that connects two wireless network segments or connects wireless and wired networks in the same way that wired bridge devices do. Wireless LAN (WLAN): A full wireless network infrastructure that serves a single physical location and is managed by a single person. Wireless survey tool: A tool for discovering wireless networks in a given area; it also records signal interferences. Wiring diagram: A wiring schematic is a document that usually consists of numerous pages and explains how the wires in a network link to switches and other nodes, what types of cables are used, and how patch panels are built. It typically includes information about each cable line. Work area: In a simple structured cabling network, an office or cubicle that may or may not contain a PC connected to the network. Workgroup: A useful technique of grouping machines in Windows operating systems under Network/My Network Places. WWW (World Wide Web): A large network of servers and clients that communicate via the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP). Accessible using graphical Web browser software such as Mozilla Firefox and Google Chrome. XOR (eXclusive OR): A common operation in cryptography. XOR takes two input bits and produces one output bit. If the input bits are the same, the result is 0, otherwise, the output is 1. Yost cable: A cable used to connect to a Cisco device. Zero-configuration networking (zeroconf): When a DHCP server is unavailable, IP addresses in the 168.254.0.0/16 subnet are generated automatically. Zero-day attack: New attack that takes advantage of a previously unknown weakness. Zero trust: A cybersecurity paradigm based on resource preservation and the notion that confidence is never granted implicitly but must be reviewed on a regular basis. ZigBee: Standard for wireless home automation control. Zombie: A single computer controlled by an operator and used in a botnet assault. Z-Wave: Standard for wireless home automation control.
